description: Protect your Django application using built-in security features and best practices.

slides.title: Built-in Protection üõ°Ô∏è
slides.content:
# Secure by Default üîí

Django takes security seriously.

It automatically protects against many common attacks:
- SQL Injection
- XSS (Cross Site Scripting)
- CSRF (Cross Site Request Forgery)
- Clickjacking

slides.title: CSRF Protection
slides.content:
# The Token üé´

Prevents malicious sites from performing actions on behalf of a user.

Django checks for a secret token in all POST requests.

Use `{% csrf_token %}` inside your `<form>`.

slides.title: SQL Injection
slides.content:
# Query Safety üíâ

Django's ORM separates query parameters from the SQL query string.

**Safe:** `Person.objects.get(name=user_input)`
**Unsafe:** `raw("SELECT * FROM ... where name = %s" % user_input)` (Avoid raw SQL unless necessary).

slides.title: XSS Handling
slides.content:
# Auto-Escaping üßº

By default, Django templates escape specific characters (`<`, `>`, `&`, `"`, `'`).

If you have `<script>alert('Hi')</script>` in a variable, it renders as harmless text, unless you explicitly mark it `safe`.

slides.title: Clickjacking
slides.content:
# Frame Busting üñºÔ∏è

Prevents your site from being put inside a `<iframe>` on another site (used to trick users into clicking hidden buttons).

`XFrameOptionsMiddleware` handles `X-Frame-Options: DENY`.

slides.title: Safety Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: How does Django primarily prevent SQL injection?
quizOptions: By using the ORM to parameterize queries automatically
It doesn't, you must sanitize inputs manually

slides.title: Host Header Validation
slides.content:
# ALLOWED_HOSTS üè†

In `settings.py`, you MUST define which domains can serve your site.

`ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['mysite.com', 'www.mysite.com']`

Prevents Host header attacks.

slides.title: SSL/HTTPS
slides.content:
# Secure Transport üîí

Use these settings in production:

- `SECURE_SSL_REDIRECT = True`
- `SESSION_COOKIE_SECURE = True`
- `CSRF_COOKIE_SECURE = True`

Ensures cookies are only sent over HTTPS.

slides.title: Password Storage
slides.content:
# Hashing üîë

Django stores passwords using strong hashing algorithms (PBKDF2 by default).

Never store passwords in plain text. Use `user.set_password()`.

slides.title: Deployment Check
slides.content:
# Audit Command üïµÔ∏è

Django includes a command to check your settings for security issues.

`python manage.py check --deploy`

slides.title: Secret Key
slides.content:
# Keep Secret Secret ü§´

`SECRET_KEY` in `settings.py` is used for signing sessions and tokens.

NEVER check this into version control. Load it from environment variables.

slides.title: Config Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which setting lists the valid domain names that your Django site can serve?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Security üõ°Ô∏è

Stay safe.

- **ORM:** Prevents SQLi.
- **Templates:** Prevent XSS.
- **CSRF Token:** Protects Forms.
- **ALLOWED_HOSTS:** Validates domain.
- **HTTPS:** Enforce secure connection.
